intro: Rhamnus alaternus var. longifolia, commonly known as the longleaf buckthorn, is a shrub or small tree native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It typically grows to a height of 2–5 meters, featuring dense, thorny branches and small, dark green leaves. The plant produces yellowish-green flowers in clusters, followed by small, fleshy berries that are edible for some birds and mammals. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in Mediterranean climates. Its botanical characteristics make it an important species in ecological studies and traditional herbal medicine.
